headline: Grandma's Slow Cooker Vegetarian Chili
description: Try this slow cooker vegetarian chili and you have a party in the making. The ingredients blend perfectly for a wonderful dish made easy in one pot.

video.description: Grandma's own hearty and comforting chili.
video.name: Grandma's Slow Cooker Vegetarian Chili

name: Grandma's Slow Cooker Vegetarian Chili
recipeIngredient: 1 (15 ounce) can kidney beans, rinsed and drained
1 (15 ounce) can garbanzo beans, rinsed and drained
1 (14.5 ounce) can chopped tomatoes in puree
1 (15 ounce) can whole kernel corn, drained
1 tablespoon chili powder, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Combine black bean soup, kidney beans, garbanzo beans, baked beans, tomatoes, corn, onion, bell pepper, and celery. Season with garlic, chili powder, parsley, oregano, and basil.
Cook on High for at least 2 hours.

review.reviewBody: A family FAVORITE or ours. I have one son who is a vegetarian and it‚Äôs the only crockpot meal that pleases everyone! My husband says he does not miss the meat and he‚Äôs a carnivore üòä! If your family likes spicy add more chili powder than recipe calls for but we love it as is! Thank you for this now ‚Äútradition‚Äù! My family calls it the ‚Äúvegetarian crock pot‚Äù!

I've been making this recipe since I found it 15 years ago. It always comes up perfect. It's easy to make and freezes well. It's always the first item to empty at a potluck. Easy to make vegan. Just make sure the baked beans are vegan and you're good to go.
This is so good. Will make it again
My Go-To for vegetarians who order meals from me. Good recipe.

To me this recipe is very good when I change the green pepper for a red bell pepper, I add about 8 oz of chipotle peppers in sauce, 1 diced sweet potato (I roasted in the oven for 5 min first after diced), and finally used one fresh jalape√±o chopped (with some seeds). The chipotle peppers adds a whole layer of flavor with a hint of sweetness/heat. On each serving I add some shredded sharp cheddar and chopped green onions on top.
good
Made it twice so. Came out very well both times. Kids loved it too.

I made this vegetarian chili for a gymnastics competition last winter. It sold out on day 1 and the concession stand requested it for day 2 of the competition. I used a packet of McCormick chili spices instead of my own individual spices. I also used a can of diced tomatoes in addition to the tomato sauce. It was a hit!

When I made it, I found that two hours in the slow cooker wasn't enough. I also found that it was better when it was kept overnight. I enjoyed it once I had kept it in the refrigerator overnight and then warmed it up in the microwave. I will make it again.

This was delish! I followed Gin Jadev‚Äôs spice combination but used the original recipe‚Äôs beans and produce combination. Plus, I used a can of black beans along with a package of Cuban black bean soup. Will definitely make again!!
Added much more seasoning!
Didn‚Äôt really care for this. Quite bland. Will not make again.
I don‚Äôt know why people always change a recipe, they put so many other things it‚Äôs not even the same recipe! You can read a recipe and know if you like it or not! Good Gosh!
This chili is beautiful! The colors are very vibrant. I added quite a bit more chili powder, oregano, and garlic for flavor.
I love this recipe combined with Rae‚Äôs vegetarian chili. The two together are my family‚Äôs favorite. Rave reviews with the combo
This was amazing! I wasn't expecting it to be so hardy. My daughter is a pescatarian and we loved it.
This is the easiest and best veggie chili. I don't use black bean soup, just the beans and I add a second can of diced tomatoes. It's even better the second day over some brown rice!

I used some homemade black bean soup & used 2 cans chopped tomatoes- 1 that I pureed w/an immersion blender. To shorten prep time, I used frozen & chopped onions & peppers & jarred minced garlic. I liked the end result & even more surprising- my non-vegetarian husband liked it too! I consider any no meat meal a success if my husband likes it!



P.S. This & many other recipes call for a couple stalks of celery. Being the only raw celery eater in my household, it is always difficult to use all the celery before it spoils. I googled freezing celery & tried the recommendations of dropping stalks in boiling water for 3 minutes & then plunged it in a ice bath, removed it & allowed it to drain throughly & froze it in freezer bags. I have used the frozen celery since & it is perfect in this recipe & others. An unexpected bonus is that it is easier to chop when frozen. Do not thaw it before chopping & adding it to your recipe & it tastes & looks like you used fresh!

I had to make some changes from the original, but it‚Äôs hard for me not to when using recipes. This recipe is pretty easy, but I have a preference for using certain techniques and adding additional flavor. I first cooked the onions and (Extra) garlic and Iadded some cut up pieces of sun dried tomatoes (maybe a tablespoon or more), and about one inch pieces of dried California and dried ancho chili‚Äôs to give it a nice complex and slightly smoky taste to go along with the sweetness, also three fresh tomatoes instead of canned. I also added a little bit of water and later some white northern beans. Otherwise I generally stuck to the recipe, cooking probably atleast 4 hours on the slow cooker setting of my instant pot. Came out delicious- it was meant for making lunches, but everyone ate it for dinner and only two portions left. I‚Äôm saving this recipe with my modifications. Thanks!
I substituted diced tomatoes , herbs and garlic for the tomatoes in pure√©. I also skipped the oregano and halved the garlic .

It was a hit, and I got lots of atta-boys for finding a recipe that tasted great and fit with my family's Daniel Fast requirements. When I make it again, I'll add mushrooms and more tomatoes and onions -- special requests.
I added half a fresh jalapeno pepper for a little kick and served it with shredded cheddar and a dollop of light sour crm. I also used can of Mexican corn instead of regular corn It was delicious!!!

I loved it but my family thought it was too sweet, so next time I am doubling the recipe, but just using 1 can of baked beans and replacing the 2nd baked beans can with more black beans. I also used plain black beans instead of black bean soup.
Loved it! I‚Äôve made it several times and I‚Äôve wowed my meat eating friends!!
good recipe, I've added extra seasoning of each to get it that right bit of flavorful

First, I found that it was very crunchy after two hours‚ÄîI then cooked it on low for a couple more hours. It has a good variety of beans plus the corn, but I thought it needed much more chili flavoring if it‚Äôs going to be called chili and not just a bean dish. I was afraid to do much because we were feeding young children, but I‚Äôd try doubling the chili powder and adding some chipotle for flavor. You could also or alternatively do some crushed red pepper. It‚Äôs not about heat‚Äîit‚Äôs about flavor development. I skipped the celery because I didn‚Äôt have any, but otherwise followed the recipe. I notice the recipe has no salt‚Äîit didn‚Äôt need it. We topped it with zero fat Greek yogurt and some shredded cheese.

I wasn‚Äôt sure how to rate this, but decided on 5 stars because if it weren‚Äôt for this recipe and the reviews from others I would not have found my all-time favorite vegetarian recipe. I kept the bean combination (shout out to the reviewer who said the black bean soup can be found in the Hispanic aisle made by Goya) andI literally nixed the rest of the recipe. Instead, into the crock pot I added the beans, 28 oz can crushed tomatoes, 14.5 oz diced tomatoes, 1 cup water or vegetable broth, 3 tbsp of Chili powder, 1 tbsp cumin, 1 - 2 chilis in adobo finely diced, 1 tsp garlic powder, 2 tsp salt, 1 can of corn at the very last minute of cooking. THE BEST CHILI I‚ÄôVE EVER HAD.
Made a few tweaks and cooked up some ground turkey on the side for the carnivores. All in all, delicious!
Easy, healthy and delicious!
This was a really good chili. That black bean soup really added to the flavor. I would highly recommend it
I add a package of beyond meat beef crumbles and even my meat eating friends devour it!

Really, really, really easy to make. Smells delicious while cooking and tastes wonderful. 

Prep was about 10 minutes (mostly opening cans and rinsing beans).

Nowhere near enough chili seasonings. Needs more chili powder, some cumin, a bit of cinnamon and allspice, and a touch of dark cocoa powder. Maybe a small can of chopped green chilis. And omit the garbanzos! Replace with white kidney beans. Oh, and a couple of bay leaves.

I made a double portion of this to enjoy now and later.The only change I made to the recipe was using cooked kidney beans I cooked instead of canned beans.It has a great flavor and with no salt in the recipe,I was surprised at how well it turned out.
It is great! Am sharing with my friends later. I know they will love it!
This was so easy to make and delicious to eat! I served it over rice for my family and replaced the meat with more beans since we are all vegetarians!
It's delicious and a simple recipe. I add half a pack of McCormick mild chili to take it to flavor town!

Added Gardein meatless ground beef, caramelized the onions and peppers before adding them to the chili, and cooked it in a pot on medium for an hour instead of a slow cooker. Came out quite tasty and flavorful. If you do it like this, don't forget to stir throughout.

I added red pepper, and jalape√±o, I used fresh corn instead of canned, and fresh spices
Served over Quinoa 
Super tasty super easy
Leftovers will be in a burrito tomorrow!
Substituted fiesta style black beans for black bean soup and chili beans for vegetarian baked beans due to availability. Both of the meat eaters in the house (including 16 year old boy) love it
Never specifically made vegetarian dishes before but my vegetarians and non-vegetarians love this chili! WIll make it again as they all raved about it.
This recipe was great! I added some zucchini to it and my family LOVED it!

The first I made it exactly as the recipe directed and it was delicious!! By the third time I was using frozen corn, dropping the baked beans, and adding pintos. By now I up the garlic, play with seasoning, use whatever veggies I have on hand, and it's still delicious!! Wonderful!
will definitely make again, used regular black beans instead of the black bean soup, great with tostito scoops!
Excellent chili, even better after a night in the fridge. Great both hot and cold.
I put only a teaspoon of chili powder and added some salt.

Not my favorite chili, but decent. Definitely too sweet, ended up adding hot chili powder, sour cream, garlic and onion powder, and hot sauce. Still has some sweetness but better than before. Cooked on high for 4-5 hours.
Delicious! I also doubled the tomatoes, doubled the garlic, added veggie crumbles and an extra can of pinto beans. I used cannellini beans instead of garbanzo beans.
Delicious! I also doubled the tomatoes, doubled the garlic, added veggie crumbles and an extra can of pinto beans. I used cannellini beans instead of garbanzo beans.

This has been a regular of mine for a long time. Instead of using canned beans I prepare the equivalent amount of dried beans ahead of time using a mix of black beans, pinto beans and kidney beans along with a half tablespoon of molasses in place of the baked beans (this chili can be very sweet as written.) The mix of spices enhances the sweetness of this chili along with the corn. If you are looking for a sweeter chili then this one is worth trying.
I‚Äôve made this so many times and it just keeps getting better. I started adding veggie ground round as a meat substitution and it‚Äôs phenomenal!
Delicious! This has replaced my own chili recipe.

It is so simple and easy! I added a 10 oz can of Rotel (hot); Progresso Reduced Sodium Southwest Style Black Bean & Vegetable soup and opted not to use the suggested spices. I ate it with warmed tortilla chips. I'm fasting so no dairy or bread this time but once fast is over, will definitely have sour cream, shredded cheese, and possibly bread on the side :-) It was absolutely delicious!
Great flavor, onions were still pretty crunchy though so I will probably cook it longer than it is recommended
super tasty. I use more chili and add chipotles gives it some heat.

We all love this- even our hard core meat eater. I swap plain black beans for the soup and a cup and a half of lentils instead of the baked beans and I add a ton more garlic and an extra onion (I blend the cooked onion with broth because I have picky eaters).

I serve this with corn bread and we eat this almost once a week.

LOVE IT
vegetarian and gluten free family loved it. Excellent protein!

Loved this recipe. Wanted to make and didn't have black bean soup on hand, so I used black beans instead. I also did not have chopped tomatoes in puree so used 1 can Rotel Fire Roasted tomatoes w/green chiles and 2 cans no salt added tomato sauce. I did add 2 extra celery stalks, 1 T brown sugar (as suggested by another reviewer), only had a red bell pepper instead of green and 12oz frozen white corn instead of canned corn; and did add 1-1/2 t. cumin and 2 bay leaves. I put in the crockpot for 5 hours on low so the spices and flavors would really blend together. It is delicious!

Loved this recipe. Wanted to make and didn't have black bean soup on hand, so I used black beans instead. I also did not have chopped tomatoes in puree so used 1 can Rotel Fire Roasted tomatoes w/green chiles and 2 cans no salt added tomato sauce. I did add 2 extra celery stalks, 1 T brown sugar (as suggested by another reviewer), only had a red bell pepper instead of green and 12oz frozen white corn instead of canned corn; and did add 1-1/2 t. cumin and 2 bay leaves. I put in the crockpot for 5 hours on low so the spices and flavors would really blend together. It is delicious!

This is a great chili recipe that I will definitely make again. I added an 8oz package of tempeh, crumbled and browned. I added one medium onion. I did not have black bean soup so I just substituted a can of black beans. I did not use baked beans since I don't like sweet chili. I did add a tablespoon of molasses, though. I also added extra chili powder, celery seed instead of celery, dry mustard, dried cilantro, smoked paprika, cumin, a few dashes of chipotle Tabasco, and a small can of mild green chilies. I going to do a double batch next time for my church pot luck.

I love this chili and so does my family and all of my meat eating friends I've made it for. I add a bag of soy crumbles and I leave out the bell pepper and parsley but those are just personal preferences. I usually double the recipe so I can freeze half. It freezes very well.
We loved it...made it with cumin, a little chipotle chili powder, and some smoked paprika. Yum!
Awesome vegetarian chili ... okay so I used maple baked beans so it wasnt official. I also used 28oz crushed tomatoes. Excellent on the first try!
Added another 28 oz can of tomatoes, used 3 Tbs of chili powder and 1 1/2 tsp if cayenne, eliminated the parsley.
Add Cumin.

Good flavour. My mods:
We don't have black bean soup so I did this: 1 can black beans + 2 c. veg broth + 1 heap tbsp of tomato paste + separate 2 tsps corn starch in warm water for thickener. Added all this in as the '1 can Black Bean Soup' that is called for.
Afterwards, some family added a bit more heat but all liked it. Next time I am going to add a bit more chili powder and more peppers - maybe a red pepper.

I didn't know chili could taste this bad. The texture with the baked beans is awful and the italian spices are weird. My kids and I could not eat it and threw it away. Never made a chili that we couldn't eat before.
I will definitely make this again! It was a hit with the whole family. The only change I made was using half the jalape√±o called for. It was spiced enough for us with out it.

I can't even count how many times I've made this. Sometimes I'm not able to find black bean soup, so I use canned black beans instead and then I use (2) of the 10oz cans of chopped tomatoes instead of (1) 14 oz. It's so good!!! I usually top it with a little plain greek yogurt and shredded cheese.
Very easy to make. Added veggie sausages for a twist.

Thanks to everyone for all the great ideas on how to improve the original recipe. But I still give the original five stars for adaptability. My adjustments for my family were as follows: no celery, added a chopped red pepper and chopped fresh jalapeno, added an extra can of red beans and leave out the sweet baked beans, leave out the Italian spices and added cumin, smoked chipotle pepper, extra can of crushed tomatoes.....delicious!!!!

Really good! Like others I had trouble finding the black bean soup that‚Äôs called for so I substituted Progresso Organic Black Bean southwest flavor and used two cans. Corn gives a slightly sweet flavor. Very flavorful and filling without being too heavy.

I made this vegetarian chili using Bush's vegetarian baked beans, canned black beans (I had no idea nor time to look for black bean "soup"), canned chili beans. Seasoned with everything listed except celery. Will eat for a couple of days then freeze the rest for later.
I replaced garbanzo beans with cauliflower. It was delicious.
This is a family favorite. I learned we prefer a can of black beans instead of Black Bean Soup. The Soup adds too much liquid and other random flavors.
YUMMY!!!!! I didn't change a thing.
Delicious! It was a great success!

First time making any type of chili or anything vegetarian in general.. I would limit the oregano and basil to half the recommended amount. I had something similar at a party and I couldn't get the recipe. This is very very close to it. I would say it tasted alot better then I thought.

My vegetarian son LOVES this stuff, and my very VERY carnivorous husband also really enjoys it. I add a tsp of chipotle smoked black pepper and a tablespoon of hickory liquid smoke. Made a pot tonight for superbowl Sunday and everyone loved it, even devout meat eaters (no worries, I also had wings & sliders LOL as well as chips, cheese and crackers, chips, nachos and some shrimp cocktail haha - GO PATS!!). I put out taco cheese and sourcream for folks to dress their own bowls. I always brown up pa half lb of ground beef the day after I make this, then spilt the leftovers in half and throw the beef in one half. My husband and son enjoy the leftovers for lunch all week
very good! very tasty. easy to make. my husband loved it. served with warm rolls and butter. this one is a keeper
Great vegetarian recipe! I've made this twice for my housemates and I and we all love it. Doesn't get easier than opening cans and chopping a few things to throw into a slow cooker.
Hubs loved and I did, also. It is very good but not tasty enough for company. It is missing something...?

We really really liked this! We have tried a couple different stews and chilis and haven't been very successful. This one was perfect. We wanted our meal very hearty this week so we added an extra can of kidney beans, carrots, and peas (I know those last two don't really go in chilis but my husband loves them). Thank you for posting this!! The presentation was beautiful too. Love the colors.

This was really delicious! I don't normally make my chili without ground beef or turkey but I tried this as one of my guests for New Year's Day Bowl game watching is. We can all do without a meat meal once and a while. Easy "Meatless Monday" recipe.

I love this! super easy- just chop a few things and throw them in the slow cooker. also super healthy. my husband and I love this and make it every few weeks.
I add avocado before serving to give it a little more flavor and texture. sometimes during football Sunday I throw some crushed up chips and mild cheddar in- that is always a huge hit!
So good. We denfinitly will be making this one again. Thanks!
It's delicious after some modifications. It does needs some liquids. I added tomato sauce, and 1 cup of water, salt, tripled the amount of chili powder, and added cheyenne.

LOVE this recipe! I've made it over a dozen times now and everyone always raves about it. This is a vegan recipe, so it's excellent for when you have to cater to a large and diverse group. My boyfriend helped me make it last week and forgot to drain the cans, but it still turned out just fine. I always add a whole head of garlic and some smoked paprika to give it a little extra smoky flavor.
Very easy, very good. I did not put celery in it, just because I don‚Äôt like celery, even cooked.

This was pretty good, but next time I would leave out the baked beans. It's too sweet for my tastes. I also followed others' instructions to cook it for 8 hours, added some cumin, sriracha, and a dash of salt as well.

This turned out delicious cooked on low setting in my slow cooker and set for eight hours. I added a organic package of crumbles keeping it all vegetarian. For the spices I substituted a package of McCormick chili spices a dash of red pepper flakes and a teaspoon of cumin. Top your bowl if chili with sour cream, snipped chives and some shredded cheddar and the end results were a perfect bowl of chili!
Loving this recipe. Warms you and fills you up!

This is a nice, easy chili recipe that is customizable and tasty. I served this at a large gathering as something more substantial alongside 18 different gourmet appetizers and it was completely cleaned out and people were asking for more. Don't listen to anyone dissing this recipe. Is it haute cuisine? No. However, as a foodie and wine enthusiast who regularly cooks gourmet meals, this is a perfectly nice little recipe for a hectic weeknight in the fall, or a large impromptu gathering.

We made a few substitutions to this awesome solid base chili recipe. We used kidney beans only and added more texture by adding mushrooms chopped into chunks. We underspiced at first and then halfed the batch and spiced over the top with a ton of cayenne pepper, paprika and a blend of jalepeno, oregano, and cheese powder(victorian epicures cheese and jalapeno dip mix). I also thickened and quickened this dish by adding potato starch and a bit of corn starch as thickeners. Sour cream and cheese are both great toppers to this dish. Thank you so much for sharing this great vegetarian chili!
I followed the recipe to a T, and it came out great! The only change I may make in the future, is adding a little more tomato sauce, as it was it bit thick after a couple of days in the fridge.

love love love this chilli!!! the only changes i made was to add another can of tomoatos that had mild chilies in it and i added a packet of mcCormick chilli powder. this was super easy to make! everyone loved it

Very good ! Couldn't find the baked beans so I just omitted it. Used a 28oz can of diced tomatoes and a 15oz can of tomato paste. Really gave it a good heartiness that I think all chili needs. Also didn't add the Italian spices and used an extra tablespoon of chili powder and added a tablespoon of cumin. Cooked on high 2 hours and low 3 hours. Personally I think it is much better the next day after sitting in the fridge overnight so all the flavours combine. Will definitely make again !
This was wonderful!!!! Added yellow and Zuchini Squash to this. Also went like on the heat. EVERYONE loved it and wanted the recipe.
This was wonderful!!!! Added yellow and Zuchini Squash to this. Also went like on the heat. EVERYONE loved it and wanted the recipe.
